What's the difference between a gene and a meme? How do they spread? What information do they carry?

In a word, genes spread vertically, and memes spread horizontally.

Clarify the definition:

A gene is hereditary information...

Narrowly speaking, we often encounter memes on social media in the form of interesting pictures or videos that are spread widely online.

More broadly, Richard Dawkins defined a meme as "an idea that rips (spreads quickly) through the public consciousness." 
Simply speaking, a meme is an idea that transmits culture through imitation and replication.

Memes are responsible for the excellent design of human culture.

Memes are like genes, but they are not passed down through parents. They are spread among people.

But I think sometimes, memes can be transmitted vertically. But most of the time, horizontally. Describe the differences between the conjugal (traditional) view of marriage and the revisionist view. What values lie at the core of each view?

Revisionist and Conjugal view on marriage represent two different views on the nature of marital unions.

The revisionist view regards marriage to be primarily an emotional bond between individuals, characterized by romantic love, mutual support, and personal fulfillment. It emphasizes the importance of each partner's agency and values the quality of the relationship with less regard for the limits of traditional structures. In revisionist marriage, the typical marriage vow "till death do you part" takes a back seat to "follow your heart."

The conjugal view regards marriage as a comprehensive union, encompassing biological, social, and emotional dimensions. It is rooted in people's belief that marriage is primarily a social institution with roles that have been defined long ago. It is often concerned with childrearing and fulfillment of family duties. In the traditional family, everyone has a role to play. The conjugal view emphasizes that the stability of the family forms the foundation of the whole society.

How does social capital help an influencer be successful?

Let's define social capital. It's a form of capital that is based on the relationships people have with others. For an influencer, social capital can consist of relationships with their followers, their reputation, and their trust network. Social capital is usually developed over a long period of time and repeated successful interactions with others.

Strong social capital can be incredibly valuable for influencers as it gives them the ability to effectively market their products or services to their followers. The product recommendations from an influencer with strong social capital are more likely to be warmly received by followers. Good social capital can help an influencer launch collaborations with some companies or brands they want to cooperate with.

In short, a successful influencer learns how to cash in on their social capital by recommending products to their followers.

Cash in

Why should we trust or not trust the recommendations from an influencer?

When considering products recommended by influencers, it's crucial to assess their motivations. Some influencers genuinely love the products they endorse, but others may be motivated by lucrative deals, partnerships, or sponsorships. We need to evaluate whether their recommendations are objective or influenced by personal feelings. After all, some influencers decide to cash in on their social capital by recommending a product they have not even tried. These influencers sell out their followers and can be regarded as paid shills.

Prioritize your own needs over trends. Reflect on whether the product actually aligns with your needs. Avoid impulse buying and make informed decisions.

In what ways does a Chinese hero differ from an American hero? Can you give one or two examples?

Chinese and American films reflect their respective underlying cultures. The heroes in Chinese and American films differ accordingly.

In American films, such as the Marvel superhero movies, each hero is unique and has special powers. This is one example of how Americans focus more on independence, self-improvement, and personal values.

While in China, people adhere more closely to collectivism and a sense of community. For example, in the film Wandering Earth, the Chinese government proposes "a community with a shared future for mankind."This film shows how a harmonious international atmosphere can overcome an existential threat to humanity.

﻿How would you prepare yourself for a hurricane or rainstorm where there will be no electricity for three days? There could be a lot of water and flooding.

It may be difficult to get your hands on food during a crisis. I would stock up on high-protein, high-calorie foods that have a long shelf life, like peanut butter and canned tuna. These foods will keep me satiated and energized during the crisis.

When the storm hits, a power outage may occur. To see clearly in the dark, I would prepare a crank-charged flashlight with built-in AM/FM radio. That way, I can stay informed of the latest developments announced through the emergency broadcast system.

To stay warm and dry, I would prepare some extra changes of clothing as well as a lightweight thermal blanket and a rain poncho.

Staying in touch with friends and family is critical. To ensure my phone stays powered and connected, I would charge a power bank in advance. If my phone battery becomes drained of power, I can easily plug it into my power bank to recharge it.

To stay hydrated, I would buy a case of bottled water in advance. Just in case, I would also buy some water purification tablets as well.

72-hour kit: backpack with emergency supplies to sustain you for three days.

What things can't you learn at school? What things cannot be taught?
Most knowledge is taught, but some things are unteachable.
Some are born with insightful intuition and deep creativity. These attributes are an innate spark�something you're born with.
Passion and drive are internal motivators that are hard to instill

What are the aims of the Federal Reserve and what tools does it use to create new money?
Central Banking System of the United States
Maximize employment, stabilize prices, moderate long term interest rates
Open market operations: The Fed prints new money to purchase financial assets such as government and corporate bonds. When the fed buys assets other than government debt, this is called quantitative easing.
Federal Funds Rate: the rate at which banks can borrow funds from the Federal Reserve. When this rate is lower, it encourages lending and investment, indirectly increasing the money supply.
Reserve requirements: the minimum reserves a bank must hold against its deposits. Modern banks engage in fractional reserve banking, which allows the bank to repurpose depositors' funds by lending them out again. However, a bank must hold a certain percentage of depositors' funds on hand in case the depositor wishes to make a withdrawal. In past years, the US Reserve Requirement Ratio was 10%. Now it is 0%. By lowering reserve requirements, the Fed allows banks to lend out a higher percentage of its deposits, thus increasing the money supply.
 
What role do protein, fat, and carbohydrates play in your body? What are some primary sources of each macronutrient?
Three essential macronutrients necessary for the overall health and well-being of our bodies.
Protein helps repair, build, and grow tissues like muscle fibers, and organs like the heart. It's found in foods like yogurt, eggs, and meat, including poultry, seafood, fish, beef, lamb, and pork. Proteins are essential for fitness enthusiasts and bodybuilders.
Fat is one of the body's two fuel sources. It provides energy for thinking and moving. We can find fats in dairy, meat, fish and edible oils. Opinions are split about which fats are healthy and which are harmful. Generally speaking, everyone agrees that unsaturated fats from fish and olive oil are healthy. However, vegetable oils have attracted much skepticism. Viewpoints diverge on the health impacts of saturated fat, which is commonly found in dairy, meat, and eggs. Consensus is clear that trans fats are harmful in all cases.
Carbohydrates are another of the body's primary energy providers. Carbohydrates can be found in rice, noodles, flour, legumes and starchy vegetables. Carbohydrates are broken down into glucose for energy. The glucose will enter our blood and trigger an increase in insulin, which signals to the cells to intake the glucose from the blood.

In your view, do the benefits of UBI outweigh the risks? Why or why not?
The concept of UBI has attracted widespread attention.
The potential drawbacks significantly outweigh its advantages.
Some UBI advocates say it would supplement existing welfare programs. Others say it would supplant them.
Its universal application ensures everyone receives a basic income, regardless of their employment status, income level, or net worth. The fact that everyone is universally eligible reduces the possibility of someone gaming the system.
Removing the current welfare system's levers and loopholes will foster social cohesion.
UBI can provide a financial cushion for those in need.

The negative side should not be ignored.
The cost would be enormous, requiring significant tax hikes or elimination of other programs. Some UBI proponents advocate for an AI or automation tax to be placed on companies that benefit most from automation.
UBI provides individuals with a guaranteed income, no strings attached.

UBI could cause a labor supply disincentive as some individuals choose to forego employment in favor of living a simple life on UBI.
The implementation of UBI will inevitably lead to economic policy reforms and significant political opposition.
Implementing such a system requires such a substantial investment of human resources, materials, and finances, all of which could be directed toward other more pressing issues.
While UBI has some merits, its drawbacks are too significant to ignore.

Describe what happens in a certain emergency or disaster. What can be done to prepare for the disaster or prevent it?
A flood is an overflow of water that submerges land that is normally dry. It can occur due to various reasons, but it always starts with heavy rainfall or a coastal storm surge.

When a flood comes, it can damage power lines and cellular towers, causing power outages and poor cellular connectivity.
In order to prepare for a flood, firstly, the government should construct and maintain dams and reservoirs to control the flow of water and reduce the risk of overflow.

The government should build a flood forecasting and warning system to enhance the capability to predict and warn of coming floods and provide valuable time for evacuation. With plenty of advance warning, citizens can leave the flood-prone danger zone in search of higher and dryer ground.

We should develop public awareness and education. Local authorities should educate the public about the risks of flooding and how to prepare for floods. Community emergency response teams (CERT) should be prepared to sandbag critical low-lying areas to direct water away from vulnerable infrastructure. Each household should prepare 72-hour kits containing first aid supplies, crank-powered flashlight and radio, walkie-talkies, high-energy, high-protein food like peanut butter and tuna fish, bottled water, water purification tablets, dry clothing and thermal blankets, and a book to keep you company.

The Broken Window Fallacy illustrates that damage is not beneficial to the economy.
The story goes as follows: A shopkeeper's son throws a rock through the shop window, shattering it into pieces. He paid the glazier six francs to repair his window. The townspeople reassured him, saying "look on the bright side! Every cloud has a silver lining. Buying a new window from the glazier gives him money to spend elsewhere, like the wine merchant or the bakery. Putting six francs into the circular economy stimulates consumption." But if we analyze the story from another angle, we come to a different conclusion. If the window hadn't been broken, the man could have bought a pair of shoes. In turn, the six francs spent on shoes would have also entered the circular economy, stimulating consumption. In both scenarios, we end up with an intact window. The difference between the scenarios is the pair of shoes that appears if the window hadn't been broken.
	The townspeople overlooked the impact of the broken window because they never saw what could have been: a new pair of shoes. This is the opportunity cost of breaking the window, and it remains in the shadows, unseen. This example teaches us the importance of paying attention to the unseen opportunity cost of every decision.

What are the differences between the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator and the Big Five?
MBTI and Big Five are two tests that measure your personality traits.
MBTI is a binary test with four dimensions: The first dimension is Extraversion versus Introversion: how do you get your energy? The second dimension is Sensing versus Intuition: how you see the world? The third dimension is Thinking versus feeling: how do you make decisions? And the fourth dimension is Judging versus Perceiving: how do you plan ahead? You can take these as your four main crutches to understand your own personality. For example, my personality type is INTJ, and I think this personality type accurately describes my personality.

Psychologists don't consider MBTI to be scientifically valid for several reasons. First of all, the MBTI presents you with a binary result. Either you're an introvert or an extravert. In reality, people may fall somewhere between the two extremes. Personality is not black and white, it's a spectrum. Secondly, the dimensions measured by MBTI were conceived by theory, not practice. This means there's no data or evidence to prove that there are only four dimensions to personality, or that the dimensions really are what the creators conceived of. For this reason, we can consider MBTI to be a useful framework for analyzing personality, but not necessarily comprehensive or conclusive.

On the other hand, the Big Five model was developed by a linguistic approach, with the assumption that words are a window to the nature of a person. Researchers used factor analysis to statistically group thousands of descriptors into five dimensions that independently co-vary. This means that each dimension is reliably separate from other dimensions.

The five dimensions of the Big Five model are conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness to experience, and extraversion. Some say that the Big Five is a value-laden framework, meaning that it's better to score low or high on a certain dimension. But value is in the eye of the beholder. Someone high in neuroticism could either be a drug addict or Steve Jobs. From this example, I assert that the Big Five doesn't need to be value-laden.

Psychologists also prefer the Big Five's assessment of personality on a spectrum rather than a binary result. A spectrum of personality better reflects reality.

	
Explain nash equilibrium and socially optimal solution using an example of �

Nash equilibrium and socially optimal solution are both important concepts in game theory. Nash equilibrium is a situation when no player can benefit by changing their strategy unilaterally. Socially optimal solution is a situation when all participants get the most collective benefit.

Hotelling's Model of Spatial Competition can help us visualize these concepts. Imagine you sell ice cream on the beach. You choose the middle of the beach because you can reach the widest range of customers from that position. One day, another vendor arrives, selling the same ice cream as you. You both agree to occupy the quarter-position on each side of the beach. This is the socially optimal solution because it minimizes the distance any beachgoer has to walk to buy ice cream. But this solution is unstable because each ice cream vendor is incentivized to move closer to the center of the beach to maximize personal interests.

When your competitor chooses to move toward the center of the beach, you are also incentivized to move to the center of the beach. The result is a Nash equilibrium, where neither of you can benefit from moving out from the center. What made gold an effective form of money?
To understand why gold was an effective form of money, we must first understand the three key characteristics of money itself: divisibility (money's ability to be divided into smaller denominations), portability (money's ability to be easily transported and transacted), and store of value (money's ability to preserve purchasing power over time).

Gold has these characteristics in abundance. Gold is divisible into small units. For very small denominations, silver was used instead. Silver and gold had a stable exchange rate.

Gold was relatively portable, especially if you stored it in a bank vault and transacted with banknotes or IOUs representing gold.

Finally, gold historically has preserved purchasing power very well. That's due in large part to its stock to flow ratio. Gold is difficult to produce in large quantities relative to its existing stock. Gold's stock to flow ratio is 66 years, which is much higher than silver or platinum. That means it would take 66 years to mine enough gold to double today's stock.

For that reason, gold's supply is nearly impossible to manipulate. This makes gold a good store of value.

The gold standard was when in the 1870s, almost all European countries accepted the value of gold, and pegged the value of their currencies to gold. Gold is a form of sound money which is resistant to manipulation.

So, why don't we transact in gold today? During the post-WWII Bretton Woods System, all global currencies were pegged to the dollar and the dollar was pegged to gold. But the United States exploited its position by printing more dollars than it had gold in the vaults. Eventually, many countries, including France, woke up to the scam and demanded gold in return for dollars.

As countries redeemed their dollars for gold, the US gold reserves began to dry up. Nixon prevented a global economic crisis by "closing the gold window," ending the dollar's convertibility to gold. Since then, all global currencies have lost their peg to gold and their value is free-floating.

﻿UBI in Korea - The Youth Basic Income Project in Gyeonggi-do
July 13, 2023 
With the concern regarding inequality and unemployment rising in South Korea, the Korean government is looking to innovate its existing redistribution strategy. There is a growing concern not just in South Korea, but around the world, that monopolies, automation, and AI technology will disrupt the labor force indefinitely. UBI (Universal Basic Income) is considered one of the most ambitious social policies of our time. Some of its renowned advocates include Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, Mark Zuckerberg the founder of Facebook, Tesla Founder Elon Musk, and former U.S. presidential candidate Andrew Yang. UBI in Korea started in  Gyeonggi-do (Province Surround Seoul) with the Youth Basic Income Program.
There are many test trials happening all across the world. More and more countries are considering UBI as an alternative to welfare. Gyeonggi-do has been operating a basic income system called Youth Basic Income. It is the 3rd largest basic income policy in the world and is being used to support young people in Gyeonggi-do that are having a hard time finding employment. In addition, Gyeonggi has established its own local currency in 31 counties and cities within Gyeonggi-do province.
UBI in Korea to Help Fight Youth Unemployment in Korea
The most common form of UBI is to give every citizen enough money to be above the poverty line. UBI in Korea has been a hot topic since 2016. South Korea has even implemented several small-scale basic income experiments run by local provinces. Back in 2019, Gyeonggi-do started the Youth Basic Income Project. It focused on paying every 24-year-old in Gyeonggi-do a basic income. The goal was to help them develop their skills so they could figure out how they will contribute to society.
Many 24-year-olds have massive pressure in Korea to find a job as quickly as possible after they graduate from university. Many don't fully know what they want to do in life. Therefore, a vast majority end up working for a company they don't care about. This can lead to depression and a lack of motivation. With the Youth Basic Income, they can now focus more on their studies or passions. For example, many can volunteer or take on social projects while they figure out what they want to do with their life.
The Youth Basic Income Project in Gyeonggi-do
There are 175,000 24-year-olds in Gyeonggi-do. Through the Youth Basic Income project, they are paid approximately $900 dollars a year (1 million won) in local currency. The local currency can be spent like cash within Gyeonggi-do. Therefore, it not only provided a basic level of income for the youth but also helped support local businesses as the money did not leave Gyeonggi-do. This is the beauty of UBI programs as it stimulates economies and increases consumption. As Andrew Yang points out, it is a trickle-up economy. The Youth Basic Income project has become the most popular policy in the province. They were even able to get actress Cho Yeo-jeong who played Mrs. Park in the Oscar-winning Korean film Parasite to do a TV commercial for basic income in Gyeonggi-do, a place she grew up in as a teenager.
If the data from the program shows promise, there is a high likelihood that this program will be implemented for all individuals in Gyeonggi-do. If we take it a step further and Gyeonggi-do shows positive results from the expanded version of the UBI, Korea will be one step closer to having Universal Basic Income in Korea.
So why start with 24-year-olds for the Youth Basic Income Project?
In Korea, 24-year-olds have just graduated from their university and are looking to enter the job market. However, many have to take additional courses or internships to improve their resume and develop the necessary skills to get a job. Furthermore, with the increase in automation and AI, the job market in Korea is extremely competitive. Therefore Gyeonggi-do decided to run the program for 24-year-olds specifically but will look to expand the program in the future. For now, this program is to help these youths and alleviate some of the pressures of early adult life.
The amount they get (approximately $900) is not enough to live on. However, the positive psychological benefits it provides can't be measured. In addition, early results show that participants are more interested in politics than before. This is because they are able to see firsthand the benefits the government can provide.

Is it economically feasible? What about inflation? Will products and services in Gyeonggi-do rise in price? These are typically the questions many critics ask when it comes to UBI projects in Korea. The Youth Basic Income project was not done by printing money but rather through a land possession tax. They collected tax from real estate and paid it back to the people. Therefore, this did not lead to inflation. Gyeonggi-do does not see this as a welfare program but rather an investment into their future through their youth. They want to encourage entrepreneurship and new technologies because this will ultimately lead to job creation.

Korea already has a welfare system that needs innovation. Taxpayer money is already going into this current system. Universal Basic Income in Korea can end these welfare systems. Just by shifting the funds, UBI in Korea can easily be financed. Governments around the world have proven they are not efficient with money.

Once they find a job, they will lose their benefits. Therefore there is less incentive to find a job. However, if citizens in Korea were getting a UBI which would be an add-on, there will be a higher incentive to find work. Also, an argument could be made that time could be much better spent looking for the right kind of job. ﻿Online discourse has never been more fragmented and conflict-ridden. Every Twitter handle loudly proclaims the moral stance of its holder, shouting to the world whether they support Ukraine or Russia,  Lockdown-ism or freedom, scientism or religion, Yankees or Knicks, Golden State Warriors or LA Lakers, or even carnivory or veganism.
People are divided along more lines than ever. Some of the most contentious divisions lie along racial and cultural lines. Many seek to embolden one side against another. Blacks against whites. Whites against blacks. Republicans against Democrats. Democrats against Republicans.
In such a contentious culture, many point to a need for more calm and civility. "If only we could be nicer to each other. If only we could have a rational conversation. If only we could sit down side by side and bridge our differences."
Others take the opposite view: opponents deserve nothing short of vigorous trolling. Give them the memes. Take the fight to them. Never relent. Flood them with propaganda. Taking a step back and viewing the contentious social situation, who in their right mind could advocate for more conflict? How on earth could the right decision be more trolling?
Is it possible that trolling and memes could be the right thing during this contentious age? I will argue yes.
Firstly, we must recognize that the internet has brought upon us an information overload. No human mind has the capacity to parse through all the data and news being constantly released to stay on top of it. How could one ever claim to understand all that is happening in our world? In my view, the world is just too complex to begin to comprehend what's going on.
A flood of information has the same effect as a drought of information: people inevitably take sides and build tribes. Communities unite around Schelling points - powerful ideological gathering points that organize the behavior and goals of their followers. Well-recognized ideological Schelling points include the environmental movement, what I call the "vaxxism" movement, the anti-vax movement, allegiance toward Russia, allegiance toward Ukraine, the capitalist ideology, the socialist ideology. Various religions have strong influence in the modern age, especially Christianity, Islam, and atheism. Young people often rally to the cry of Black Lives Matter, or the LGBT movement, or the feminist movement. Others seek to wage memetic battle in the world of finance by supporting this or that cryptocurrency.
There are simply endless causes to unite oneself to and fight for. There's not enough time to figure out who's right and who's wrong. Can we expect that all these sides can just sit down and have a rational conversation? I highly doubt it.
Instead, I believe that the differences between these ideologies are being resolved on a different playing field: the memetic playing field. He who controls the memes controls the world. Promoting a logical conversation will do nothing if your opponent obliterates your position with a devastating meme, even if it's not accurate!
What determines how people take up sides? I believe that people make decisions not primarily based on logic, but based on rhetoric. Which side has the more immediately convincing arguments? Which side seems cooler? Better? Stronger? This is determined not by logical discussion, but by memes.

﻿	Vegetable oil first appeared on the American market in the early 1900s. After Proctor and Gamble developed methods for transforming the husks of cottonseeds into soap, they discovered that the soap resembled lard, and could be sold as a replacement for animal fat. The company launched a marketing campaign aimed at replacing animal fats with their new product made from industrial seed oils called Crisco. The campaign was massively successful.
	Heart disease was a rarity before the 1920s, but with cases on the rise, Americans began to pay more and more attention. After president Eisenhower had a heart attack, public attention was fixated on heart disease and its possible causes. Although Eisenhower was a chain smoker, blame was laid at the feed of saturated fats, the type of fat common in butter, cream, tallow, and lard. According to nutritionist Ancel Keys, Americans were consuming too much saturated fat.
	A particularly effective, but misleading meme emerged which envisioned saturated fat as hot oil being poured down a cold pipe. One undoubtedly visualizes the oil sticking to the sides of the pipe, turning solid, and coagulating into a blob of solid mass, preventing the flow of anything through the pipe. This meme spread like wildfire among the American public, which in short time radically decreased its consumption of saturated fats.
	But what to replace it with? Proctor and Gamble paid the American Heart Association millions of dollars to promote its so-called healthy alternative to saturated fat: vegetable oil. Deceptively named, it is actually made from the industrial byproduct of seeds, through an extensive and grueling chemical and heat process. The result is a clear-looking liquid, which by its looks, is totally safe to consume. However, this is far from the truth.
	Vegetable oils contain a high ratio of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs). These molecules have several "bends" in the molecule, due to the missing hydrogens at several points. The names "omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acid" refer to this distinction of how many bends are in the molecule. Because of these bends, the oil is easily broken down into sub-molecules when heated to high temperatures.
	After switching from animal fats to vegetable oil, restaurants have been experiencing cleaning problems with grungy oil getting stuck to the floors, walls, ceilings, and surfaces of the kitchen. This grunge is not just oil - it is the broken-down polymers resulting from heating vegetable oil. These polymers have the same effect as varnish for furniture. What's more, uniforms saturated with vegetable oil have been known to spontaneously combust in storage bins or dryers. The broken-down polymers of vegetable oils have been known to cause many diseases. It's likely that vegetable oil is one of the culprits behind the American chronic disease and obesity epidemic.
	After all, consumption of vegetable oil has increased dramatically since the 1950s, at a rate higher than any other food product. With such a dramatic rise in rates of chronic disease and obesity, there's only one food product whose consumption matches such a trajectory: vegetable oil.

David Hepworth (left) and Chase Roberts (right) founded the BYU Lunch app. (Photo by Sarah Hill)
"There are a lot of events on campus that offer free food, but because of a limited ability to reach out to all students not everyone gets the message," Hepworth said. "The app helps to put the message of free food giveaways or organization events in one easy and quick accessible place � on your cell phone or computer."
The cell phone app, which was launched two weeks ago, already has a little over 400 student downloads, and both Hepworth and Roberts predict that by the end of the month, 1,000 students will download it.
The app is free to download and helps promote clubs and organizations, featuring a list of events that are offering free food.
Dave Conley, who is studying molecular biology, first heard about the BYU Lunch Box app in his physics class after he saw information about the app written on the whiteboard.
"I like how this app makes students aware of free food on campus and also informs students of events," Conley said. "This app, I feel, raises awareness of organizations and clubs that some students may have never known existed."
As many college students know, free food is always a plus of college life, but do organizations and clubs feel taken advantage of when students just drop in for a bite and leave right after?
Jonathan Shumway, an officer of the BYU Pre-med Club, hesitated when he first heard about the app.
"When I first heard about the app from David, who asked if he could advertise that the (pre-med) club was having free pizza, I had my doubts," Shumway said. "I felt students would only come for the food. After thinking more about it, I realized that the app was a great publicity tool and would build awareness of our club."
The app's format provides lists of upcoming events, what food will be offered, which organizations are sponsoring them and when they will take place. The app also displays the events weeks in advance so students can plan their schedules accordingly.
The BYU Lunch Box app isn't just for students with smartphones. Students without smartphones can receive updates on free food events on campus through the BYU Lunch Box website, Facebook page or Twitter.
"We want our app to be available to every student, and by putting it online we can reach students who don't have smartphones, allowing students without smartphones to receive updates on upcoming food events on campus," Hepworth said.
Hepworth and Roberts strive to make the app more user friendly and are constantly looking for ways to improve it. Recently, they had an idea of allowing students to click on an "I'm attending" button so clubs and organizations know how much food to plan for.
"We feel that something like this can reduce stress and help organizations and clubs plan the right amount of food and space they need to fit the needs of the event," Roberts said.
Hepworth and Roberts, who anticipate graduation in the near future, hope their app will become big enough that students will update it regularly about free food events without their help.
"Our hope is that this app will continue after we leave BYU," Roberts said. "I plan to stay in Provo a while after I graduate so I can work for start-up companies, allowing me to check on the app's progress on a daily basis. My dream is that someday this app will become self-sustaining."

Winners and losers of globalization
Although it's said that "a rising tide lifts all boats," globalization has not benefitted everyone equally. Over the past forty years, some groups have seen their incomes rapidly rise, whereas others have only seen stagnation. I will describe below the winners and losers of globalization.
*elephant chart
	After China's reform and opening up in 1979, foreign companies invested massive resources into the country, bringing opportunity and growth. A similar growth occurred in India. Between these two countries, a huge part of the world's population was lifted out of poverty. Having gained access to clean water and healthcare, life expectancy and quality of life rose. This group, known as the "global middle class" is one of the undisputed winners of globalization. 
	On the other side of the spectrum, the global elite, known as "plutocrats" have also profited from the surge in globalization. The CEOs and managers of finance and tech companies have outsourced labor to cheaper offshore workers, and as a result, have widened their profit margins substantially. Technology has allowed these companies to access billions of global customers in every market. High-level workers at these companies have been rewarded handsomely for their efforts.
	Although the upper class in developed countries has risen to the top, the lower and middle classes in the same countries have stagnated. In countries such as the United States, Japan, and Germany, where manufacturing once reigned supreme, workers have been left jobless, without a promotion or advancement in 40 years. These unfortunate people constitute the "losers" of globalization. Their jobs have been outsourced to developing nations, while the upper class rises higher and higher.
	Globalization has been a boon for the global middle class and the global elite, while it has left the middle class of developed nations in the dust. Time will tell if this trend will continue or somehow reverse.

Gender Equality Gap

In 2022, men and women continue to be treated differently at work. The most striking areas of concern are the gender pay gap, gender distribution imbalances, and sexual harassment. Everyone agrees that harassment is unacceptable, but not everyone agrees on the source of the gender pay gap or gender distribution imbalances within various industries like STEM. Some countries, like Sweden, have sought to close the pay gap by equalizing gender distribution in the workplace. Official government policies seek to give companies in typically male-dominated industries benefits for hiring women, and impose penalties for hiring men. This, among other policies, constitutes part of Sweden's mission to be the world's "most feminist government."
	Experts believed that these gender equality policies would lead to a rise in female participation in STEM. However, researchers were shocked to find the exact opposite phenomenon. Since implementing these policies, female participation in STEM has actually dropped! This is known as the gender equality paradox. In the years following this research, experts have attempted to explain the reason for the unexpected result. Some experts suspect that the root cause may be biological, whereas others suspect that cultural factors are at play.
	Sweden's high quality of life affords people the freedom to choose their career free from economic concerns. Someone who is willing to work in a typically low-paying field is free to follow their heart. The government provides free education, healthcare, and many social benefits. Income is no longer a primary concern for Swedish young people. If this is the case, then men and women are free to pursue their natural talents and passions. It's possible that the reduction in female participation in STEM represents the freedom of women to pursue a different field they prefer even more.
	On the other hand, we must account for the centuries-long exclusion of women from STEM in Europe. This gender stereotype has persisted until today, and according to many, is even intensifying. In contrast, other countries like Algeria, Turkey, and Iran, see high female participation in STEM, possibly because no such gender stereotypes have prevented women from entering STEM in the past. Some of the world's greatest female mathematicians and scientists have come from countries with little gender equality.

Content types and MT

Although the content explosion requires more translation than ever, the current pool of translators and interpreters simply can't meet the huge demand. Companies are now considering the use of MT for certain types of content. Which types of content are suitable for MT and which are not? I will explain below.
	MT is not appropriate for high-value, high-visibility, high-creativity content. The front page of your website deserves the touch of a human expert. The translated PowerPoint presentation your boss will give on a foreign business trip, should be thoroughly reviewed by a senior linguist. Subtitles for a film or video require the creative intuition of an experienced translator.
	But what about the instructions for a medical device? Certainly MT is not appropriate for such a mission-critical document. You may be surprised to find out that MT is a great choice for this kind of content, as long as a qualified human post-editor reviews the raw MT output. What makes this kind of content appropriate for MT? Technical writing tends to use short sentences, clear terminology, simple sentence structure, and unambiguous language. All these factors result in a machine translation output that is remarkably accurate.
Although MT makes mistakes from time-to-time, consider that human translators aren't perfect either! Mistakes made by humans may be harder to spot, whereas mistakes made by MT can be easily identified and fixed.
Finally, there are some types of content which are suitable for MT with no human post-editing required. Patent lawyers use MT to get the gist of a document. Foodies and travelers use MT to read online reviews posted in other languages. EBay uses MT to make product listings available to anyone around the globe. Some product documentation or "instructions for use" are produced with MT. The bottom line is this: if you can understand the basic meaning, it's good enough.

Bike safety is a big topic. Wear a helmet. Follow traffic laws, like halting at stop signs. Don't go too fast, and make sure your brakes work.
This is all useful advice. It has been beat over my head since elementary school. Nonetheless, it didn't help me from getting into bike accidents during college. To tackle that problem, I took advice that depended on game theory and the concept of focal points.
Focal Points
Imagine you and a partner are in an experiment. Each of you will be shown a diagram of four boxes and asked to pick one. You will not be allowed to communicate with your partner.
If you manage to pick the same box as your partner, then you both get $10. If not, then both of you go home empty-handed.
Suppose you are playing the game. What box would you pick?
/
It turns out that the strategy is tremendously simple: for each box your partner picks, you will simply match the pick. The hard part is figuring out what your partner will guess since you cannot communicate with each other.
As you can see, this game has a sense of "team spirit." Both players would like to pick corresponding strategies for mutual gain. We play these types of games often�an example that comes to mind is how friends coordinate outfits, so no two people end up wearing the same thing. Appropriately, such games go by the name of coordination games.
There is no box that's "better" than another one. The payoff is simply dependent on picking the same one. If you and your partner are good friends, you might have common knowledge about each other to help you win. You might pick box four, for example, because you know it is your friend's favorite number.
But what if you and your partner were complete strangers? How might you arrive at the same box?
As the problem is stated, there is no particular box that is better to pick. Both of you would go about picking numbers randomly and just accept the 25% random chance of winning (4 winning pairs out of a possible 16).
But now let's say the experiment was slightly changed. Imagine instead of being faced with four identical boxes, you and your partner were shown a diagram like this:
/
Now, which box would you choose?
As you can see, box two is specially marked in red. You might realize that it stands out, and suspect that it would also stand out to your partner, the complete stranger. And that's the trick.
The special marking makes both players pick box two "naturally." It's a form of organizing and communicating without actually being able to talk. Remember, there is nothing special about picking box two. The other equilibriums are the players both picking any of the other boxes. What makes box two special is the marking and attraction to it as a choice.
Such an equilibrium earns the fitting name of focal point. It is also known by the name Schelling point, in honor of the game theorist Thomas Schelling, who introduced the concept in his 1960 book The Strategy of Conflict.
It is worth noting that focal points are dependent on social beliefs. In America, I would think most experiment participants would pick box two because it stood out.
But I can imagine this is not necessarily true cross-culturally. It is possible in another culture that it's considered bad luck to pick the prominent square. Under that system, the natural choice would be never pick box two.
This is helpful knowledge. Eliminating one choice raises the chances of success from 25 percent to just over 33 percent.
The Bike Game
Avoiding bike crashes is type of coordination game. Bikers want to coordinate to avoid occupying the same real estate at the same time.
Let's start with a simplified version of the game with two bikers moving in opposing directions:
/
 
To simplify matters, we can say that each biker has a choice of going straight, moving to his left, or moving to his right.
Crashes occur when both bikers go straight, or when they both swerve to the same path�either left or right.
/
The remaining combinations, say one goes straight and other swerves right, will result in a safe exchange. There are six "safe" cases compared to the three "crash" cases.
Thanks to the nature of the game, by random chance, it's twice as likely that the bikers will avoid each other than crash.
Furthermore, there is a focal point that can reduce crashes. We Americans drive on the right hand side of the road, so it is natural that both bikers would swerve to their respective right side.
This rule of thumb helps avoid crashes. Plus, it doubles as a good tip for walking in hallways of American offices.
/
Unfortunately, our friendly human nature tends to undermine the safe focal point. What many of us do is get nervous and try to make eye contact with the other biker.
When you make eye contact, you feel the need to mirror what the other person is doing. Because you have limited time to respond, you don't react fast enough. You even ruin the random chance of a safe passage and make crash the likely course.
And that' why the best advice I ever got about bike safety was this rule: avoid eye contact with an oncoming biker. It's not mind-blowing advice, nor does it always seem nice, but it is very practical. When you don't stare at the other person, you both will rely on the focal point of swerving to the right.
(My friends and I joked that the "no stare" advice is virtually impossible to follow when the oncoming biker is attractive. But then the game is different, as you probably wouldn't mind bumping into that person and starting up a conversation).
Some Students Make the Game More Difficult

There may come a day when you suddenly realize that the price level is incomparable to that of 20 years ago, and this is the impact of inflation on our lives. Inflation is constantly occurring as the purchasing power of the national currency continues to decrease. The causes of inflation can be summarized as follows: firstly, inflation occurs when the growth rate is too fast due to the increase in money issuance by the central bank; secondly, people's demand increases, which may be due to a general rise in purchasing power or population growth; thirdly, inflation also occurs when the country's currency depreciates, leading to higher import prices; fourthly, rising production costs also contribute to price growth. I believe moderate inflation is acceptable. To my knowledge, China's annual inflation rate is about 3%. Although it is a modest number, it also means that the cash you keep at home will depreciate at the same rate. Only by allowing our money to flow can we avoid inflation eroding our wealth.

    When the money supply increases, the individuals or organizations that first come into contact with the new money are able to benefit from its increase. However, as money gradually circulates in the economy, price increases gradually occur, resulting in losses for those who come into contact with the currency at a later stage. This redistribution of wealth is caused by the increase in prices resulting from the increase in money, leading to the early acquirers of money benefiting in terms of purchasing power, while those who acquire money later experience a loss in purchasing power. This is known as the Cantillon effect. It reveals an economic phenomenon where the Cantillon effect generally has a negative impact on the masses who are the last to come into "contact" with the released money.

The aims of the fed includes maximizing employment, stabilizing prices to prevent inflation and deflation, and moderating long-term interest rates. Open market operations is how the Fed creates new money to purchase financial assets, which is known as quantitative easing and increases the money supply. While the discount rate is the short-term borrowing rate between banks that all other interest rates are based on. The lower the rate, the easier and more cost-effective it is to borrow money, leading to growth in the money supply. Finally, reserve requirements are the minimum amount of reserves that banks must hold. Lowering the minimum bar means more money is released by the bank, so the money supply also grows.

Rai stones and aggry beads are two different forms of currency that were used in different regions throughout history. 
In Micronesian Island of Yap, rai stones were highly valued due to their unforgeable nature. These massive stones required significant manpower to transport from other islands. Transactions and ownership of them were recorded through oral means. However, the weight of rai stones made their transportation arduous, and the transaction process was prone to errors. Additionally, with the arrival of the colonizers, rai stones gradually fell out of use and were eventually demonetized.
Compared to rai stones, the aggry beads were smaller and more portable. Glass aggry beads were used as currency in West Africa as early as the 15th century. Since glassmaking technology was scarce and expensive in Africa, aggry beads were well-suited to serve as a medium of exchange in the local area. However, with the advancement of glassmaking technology in European countries, colonizers took advantage of the situation. They exploited the resources, labor, and people of West Africa by manufacturing fake beads at low cost. As a result, the rarity of aggry beads diminished, leading to a decrease in their value. Consequently, people became more inclined to use the high-value currencies of the colonizers, such as the British pound or the US dollar.

﻿What is the significance of August 15th, 1971?

On August 15th, President of the United States Richard Nixon announced his New Economic Policy, a program that "closed the gold window." Known as the "Nixon Shock", the incident marked the beginning of the end of the Bretton Woods system.

Under the Bretton Woods System, the values of foreign currencies were fixed in relation to the U.S. dollar. However, when the United States experienced domestic inflation after World War II and didn't have enough gold to cover the volume of dollars in worldwide circulation, the dollar was overvalued. Then, traders in foreign markets turned to believe that the dollar's overvaluation would one day force the U.S. government to devalue it. As a result, they decided to sell their U.S. dollars and exchange them for gold as a store of value. 

On the evening of August 15, President Nixon announced his New Economic Policy in an address to the nation on "The Challenge of Peace." To face the challenges of a post-Vietnam world and "protect the dollar from the attacks of international money speculators", Nixon directed the suspension of the dollar's convertibility into gold. This proposal meant the end of the Bretton Woods system established after World War II, and also became the catalyst for the stagflation of the 1970s in the whole world.

How, began Compton, should we think about the debate over technological unemployment�"the loss of work due to obsolescence of an industry or use of machines to replace workmen or increase their per capita production"? He then posed this question: "Are machines the genii which spring from Aladdin's Lamp of Science to supply every need and desire of man, or are they Frankenstein monsters which will destroy man who created them?" Compton signaled that he'd take a more grounded view: "I shall only try to summarize the situation as I see it."

Some leading Silicon Valley techno-optimists even postulate that we're headed toward a jobless future where everything can be done by AI.

For "industry as a whole," he concluded, "technological unemployment is a myth." Compton, a physicist, was the first chair of a scientific advisory board formed by Franklin D. Stark reported recently gathered data on the strong productivity gains from new machines and production processes in various sectors, including the cigar, rubber, and textile industries. In theory, as Compton argued, that meant more goods at a lower price, and�again in theory�more demand for these cheaper products, leading to more jobs. But as Stark explained, the worry was: How quickly would the increased productivity lead to those lower prices and greater demand?  
As Stark put it, even those who agreed that jobs will come back in "the long run" were concerned that "displaced wage-earners must eat and care for their families 'in the short run.'"

Lessons for our current AI era can be drawn not just from the 1930s but also from the early 1960s. Unemployment was high. Some leading thinkers of the time claimed that automation and rapid productivity growth would outpace the demand for labor. In 1962, MIT Technology Review sought to debunk the panic with an essay by Robert Solow, an MIT economist who received the 1987 Nobel Prize for explaining the role of technology in economic growth and who died late last year at the age of 99. 
In his piece, titled "Problems That Don't Worry Me," Solow scoffed at the idea that automation was leading to mass unemployment. Productivity growth between 1947 and 1960, he noted, had been around 3% a year. "That's nothing to be sneezed at, but neither does it amount to a revolution," he wrote. No great productivity boom meant there was no evidence of a second Industrial Revolution that "threatens catastrophic unemployment." But, like Compton, Solow also acknowledged a different type of problem with the rapid technological changes: "certain specific kinds of labor � may become obsolete and command a suddenly lower price in the market � and the human cost can be very great."
These days, the panic is over artificial intelligence and other advanced digital technologies. Like the 1930s and the early 1960s, the early 2010s were a time of high unemployment, in this case because the economy was struggling to recover from the 2007�'09 financial crisis. It was also a time of impressive new technologies. Smartphones were suddenly everywhere. Social media was taking off. There were glimpses of driverless cars and breakthroughs in AI. Could those advances be related to the lackluster demand for labor? Could they portend a jobless future?

In a story I wrote titled "How Technology Is Destroying Jobs," economist Erik Brynjolfsson and his colleague Andrew McAfee argued that technological change was eliminating jobs faster than it was creating them. This wasn't just about a mill shutting down. But it was becoming increasingly obvious, both in the data and in everyday observations, that new technologies were changing the types of jobs in demand�and while that was nothing new, the scope of the transition was troubling, and so was the speed at which it was happening. Industrial robots had killed off many well-paying manufacturing jobs in places like the Rust Belt, and now AI and other digital technologies were coming after clerical and office jobs�and even, it was feared, truck driving.
In his farewell speech before leaving office in January 2017, President Barack Obama spoke about "the relentless pace of automation that makes a lot of good middle-class jobs obsolete." By that time, it was clear that Compton's optimism needed to be rethought. Technical progress was not turning out to lead to inevitable job growth, and the pain was not limited to a few specific locations and industries.

It might not be possible to prove Musk wrong, since he gave no timeline for his utopian prediction; in any case, how do you argue against the power of a magical genie? But the end-of-work meme is a distraction as we figure out the best way to use AI to expand the economy and create new jobs.
Breakthroughs in generative AI, such as ChatGPT and other large language models, will likely transform the economy and labor markets. But there's no convincing evidence that we're on a path to a jobless future. To paraphrase Solow, we should worry about that when there's a problem to worry about.
Even a bullish estimate about the effects of generative AI by Goldman Sachs puts its impact on productivity growth at around 1.5% a year over the next 10 years. That, as Solow might say, is nothing to sneeze at, but it's not going to end the need for workers. The Goldman Sachs report calculated that roughly two-thirds of US jobs are "exposed to some degree of automation by AI." Yet this conclusion is often misinterpreted�it doesn't mean all those jobs will be replaced. Rather, as the Goldman Sachs report notes, most of these positions are "only partially exposed to automation." For many of these workers, AI will become part of the workday and won't necessarily lead to layoffs.
The end-of-work meme is a distraction as we figure out the best way to use AI to expand the economy and create new jobs.
One critical wild card is how many new jobs will be created by AI even as existing ones disappear. Estimating such job creation is notoriously difficult. But MIT's David Autor and his collaborators recently calculated that 60% of employment in 2018 was in types of jobs that didn't exist before 1940. One reason innovation has created so many new jobs is that it has increased the productivity of workers, augmenting their capabilities and expanding their potential to do new tasks. The bad news: this job creation is countered by the labor-destroying impact of automation when it's used to simply replace workers. As Autor and his coauthors conclude, one of the key questions now is whether "automation is accelerating relative to augmentation, as many researchers and policymakers fear."
In recent decades, companies have often used AI and advanced automation to slash jobs and cut costs. There's no economic rule that innovation will in fact favor augmentation and job creation over this type of automation. But we have a choice going forward: we can use technology to simply replace workers, or we can use it to expand their skills and capabilities, leading to economic growth and new jobs.
One of the lasting strengths of Compton's 1938 essay was his argument that companies needed to take responsibility for limiting the pain of any technological transition. His suggestions included "co�peration between industries of a community to synchronize layoffs in one company with new employment in another." That might sound outdated in today's global economy. But the underlying sentiment remains relevant: "The fundamental criterion for good management in this matter, as in every other, is that the predominant motive must not be quick profits but best ultimate service of the public."
At a time when AI companies are gaining unprecedented power and wealth, they also need to take greater responsibility for how the technology is affecting workers. Conjuring up a magical genie to explain an inevitable jobless future doesn't cut it. We can choose how AI will define the future of work.

The discourse surrounding automation and artificial intelligence often pivots around a central anxiety: the potential displacement of human labor. At the heart of this philosophical examination lies the concept of entropy, a term borrowed from thermodynamics, which describes the inherent tendency of natural systems to degrade into disorder. Human civilization, in its unyielding quest for stability and progress, has harnessed technology and automation as bulwarks against this natural decay. From rudimentary tools to sophisticated AI systems, our innovations serve as mechanisms to secure resources, enhance productivity, and ultimately, ensure the continuation and enrichment of human life.
The narrative of technological unemployment, therefore, must be situated within a broader context of evolving human values and aspirations. Work, initially centered around the necessities for survival such as food production and shelter construction, has progressively transformed into more nuanced and diverse forms as technology alleviates the burden of basic sustenance. This shift mirrors Maslow's hierarchy of needs, where once the foundational requirements of physiological and safety needs are met, individuals can aspire towards self-actualization through creative, intellectual, and social endeavors.
The concern that automation may render jobs obsolete overlooks the dynamic nature of human desires and the adaptability of economies. As history attests, from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age, each wave of technological disruption has led not to widespread idleness but to the creation of new industries and forms of employment. The notion of 'value-driven action,' as posited, underscores this transition; as survival becomes less arduous, work evolves to embody higher-order values such as aesthetics, innovation, and personal fulfillment.
This philosophical stance aligns with the post-work theories, which posit that advancements in technology could potentially liberate humans from compulsory labor, allowing society to redefine the meaning and purpose of work. However, it also intersects with critiques of capitalism, highlighting the unequal distribution of productive assets. In this view, the fear of job loss stems from a systemic issue where the majority, lacking ownership of the means of production, are dependent on employment for survival. This echoes Marxist critiques, where the bourgeoisie's control over capital perpetuates a cycle of exploitation and alienation among the proletariat.
Yet, the analogy to the Renaissance period, where patronage by the affluent facilitated artistic and cultural revolutions, offers a nuanced perspective. It suggests that under a scenario of reduced labor demand, those who control substantial productive assets could potentially drive a new era of sponsored creativity and intellectual pursuits, akin to the Medici family's role in fostering the Italian Renaissance. Here, the future of work is reimagined as less about conventional jobs and more about aligning individual talents with the values and desires of asset owners, thereby sustaining a cycle of mutual benefit and societal enrichment.
In conclusion, the philosophical inquiry into automation's impact on jobs transcends a simplistic dichotomy of job loss versus retention. Instead, it prompts a deeper reflection on the essence of human progress, the evolution of labor in response to technological advancements, and the need for a societal recalibration that ensures equitable access to the fruits of automation. By recognizing the potential for a post-scarcity society, where human creativity and value-driven pursuits are prioritized, we can begin to construct a vision of the future that transcends traditional employment models and embraces a more holistic understanding of human flourishing.

Technical progress was not turning out to lead to inevitable job growth, and the pain was not limited to a few specific locations and industries.
Why Musk is wrong
In an interview late last year with the UK prime minister, Rishi Sunak, Elon Musk declared there will come a time when "no job is needed," thanks to an AI "magic genie that can do everything you want." Musk added that as a result, "we won't have universal basic income, we'll have universal high income"�apparently answering Compton's rhetorical question about whether machines will be "the genii which � supply every need and desire of man." 
It might not be possible to prove Musk wrong, since he gave no timeline for his utopian prediction; in any case, how do you argue against the power of a magical genie? But the end-of-work meme is a distraction as we figure out the best way to use AI to expand the economy and create new jobs.
Breakthroughs in generative AI, such as ChatGPT and other large language models, will likely transform the economy and labor markets. But there's no convincing evidence that we're on a path to a jobless future. To paraphrase Solow, we should worry about that when there's a problem to worry about.
Even a bullish estimate about the effects of generative AI by Goldman Sachs puts its impact on productivity growth at around 1.5% a year over the next 10 years. That, as Solow might say, is nothing to sneeze at, but it's not going to end the need for workers. The Goldman Sachs report calculated that roughly two-thirds of US jobs are "exposed to some degree of automation by AI." Yet this conclusion is often misinterpreted�it doesn't mean all those jobs will be replaced. Rather, as the Goldman Sachs report notes, most of these positions are "only partially exposed to automation." For many of these workers, AI will become part of the workday and won't necessarily lead to layoffs.
The end-of-work meme is a distraction as we figure out the best way to use AI to expand the economy and create new jobs.
One critical wild card is how many new jobs will be created by AI even as existing ones disappear. Estimating such job creation is notoriously difficult. But MIT's David Autor and his collaborators recently calculated that 60% of employment in 2018 was in types of jobs that didn't exist before 1940. One reason innovation has created so many new jobs is that it has increased the productivity of workers, augmenting their capabilities and expanding their potential to do new tasks. The bad news: this job creation is countered by the labor-destroying impact of automation when it's used to simply replace workers. As Autor and his coauthors conclude, one of the key questions now is whether "automation is accelerating relative to augmentation, as many researchers and policymakers fear."
In recent decades, companies have often used AI and advanced automation to slash jobs and cut costs. There's no economic rule that innovation will in fact favor augmentation and job creation over this type of automation. But we have a choice going forward: we can use technology to simply replace workers, or we can use it to expand their skills and capabilities, leading to economic growth and new jobs.
One of the lasting strengths of Compton's 1938 essay was his argument that companies needed to take responsibility for limiting the pain of any technological transition. His suggestions included "co�peration between industries of a community to synchronize layoffs in one company with new employment in another." That might sound outdated in today's global economy. But the underlying sentiment remains relevant: "The fundamental criterion for good management in this matter, as in every other, is that the predominant motive must not be quick profits but best ultimate service of the public."
At a time when AI companies are gaining unprecedented power and wealth, they also need to take greater responsibility for how the technology is affecting workers. Conjuring up a magical genie to explain an inevitable jobless future doesn't cut it. We can choose how AI will define the future of work.
